JUDGES: Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Ineta Ziemele;Ján Šikuta;Josep Casadevall;Kristina Pardalos;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE , in GPE . He was represented before the ORG by Mr D. Strupek , a lawyer practising in GPE . The applicant has requested anonymity and the ORG has granted this request , under LAW § CARDINAL of the Rules of Court .
CARDINAL . The Government of GPE ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant is of NORP origin and works as a social and human rights worker and psychologist . He has been living in GPE since DATE .
CARDINAL . PERSON is a village in northern GPE with population of around QUANTITY inhabitants .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( “ the municipal council ” ) passed a resolution changing the name of a street in the village to Dr. PERSON .
CARDINAL . After protests by CARDINAL local organisations , the resolution was confirmed by a second resolution of the municipal council on DATE . The resolution reads as follows :
“ ORG , by way of resolution No . CARDINAL of DATE , adopted a change in the name of the street ... to Dr. PERSON ( ulica Dr. PERSON ) .... ”
CARDINAL . According to an official statement of ORG of CARDINAL DATE sent to the applicant upon his own request ,

“ ... J. Tiso was the head of ORG DATE who collaborated with NORP GPE and waged war against the [ ORG ] States . Moreover , under his leadership a totalitarian regime of a fascist character was established , which , inter alia , caused the violent deaths of CARDINAL of its citizens . PERSON , as the Prime Minister [ and ] President of the ORG and as the President of the sole governing [ party ] , the ORG , as the top commander of the ORG ’s army and as the top commander of ORG , bears the greatest part of the political , legal and moral responsibility for all the events in the NORP State during the war . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the municipal council asked ORG of ORG to submit an official opinion on the change of the street ’s name .
CARDINAL . In its opinion of CARDINAL DATE ORG did not recommend naming the street after Dr. PERSON , “ since the personality of Dr. PERSON has not yet been historically assessed ” .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant unsuccessfully sought to initiate criminal proceedings . In DATE he brought a civil claim , mainly seeking the quashing of the municipal council ’s resolution , renaming of the street and payment of symbolic compensation . Both his civil claim and his subsequent constitutional complaints against the decisions of the prosecution service and the courts were dismissed . The details are described below .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant unsuccessfully sought to initiate criminal proceedings concerning the adoption of the above - mentioned municipal resolution on DATE . In DATE the applicant also unsuccessfully sought to initiate criminal proceedings against the police investigator who had dismissed the applicant ’s criminal complaint . Both complaints were dismissed by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , exercising its power to review the lawfulness of actions and decisions of public authorities , notified the municipal council that the renaming of the street was in breach of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of ORG . That section provides that the names of streets are to be determined by municipal councils after taking into account an opinion of ORG established by ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP By letter of DATE the municipal council informed ORG that its letter had been discussed by the municipal council .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a petition with ORG seeking a ruling declaring that the naming of the street after Dr. PERSON was in breach of LAW . He requested that the relevant part of the municipal council ’s resolution be declared null and void and be quashed , that the street be renamed and that the municipal council be ordered to pay symbolic compensation of CARDINAL NORP koruna ( SKK ) to all registered churches in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG invited the applicant to provide further and more specific particulars of claim .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant amended his claim with regard to the renaming of the street and changed it with regard to the compensation sought by requesting that a symbolic sum of SKK CARDINAL be paid to him .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG hived off the part of the applicant ’s claim concerning the validity of the resolution to separate proceedings . On DATE ORG dismissed these proceedings , holding that it had no jurisdiction to examine the legality of the municipal council ’s resolution and transferred the case to ORG .

CARDINAL . By letter of DATE ORG returned the case file to ORG without having made a decision . It stated that proceedings before ORG could not be initiated by a case being transferred to it by an ordinary court .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG informed the applicant of ORG letter and concluded that the decision to dismiss the proceedings concerning the validity of the resolution was final and the case file would be archived .

CARDINAL . Meanwhile , on DATE , ORG had informed the applicant that his claim for the renaming of the street and for payment of compensation fell to be determined within the framework of the protection of his personal integrity . It transferred the case to ORG , as the matter lay within that court ’s territorial jurisdiction .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the proceedings and transferred the case to ORG , holding that it had no jurisdiction to deal with the case .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed against the decision .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG amended its decision of CARDINAL DATE , in that it hived off the applicant ’s claim for payment of SKK CARDINAL in compensation to a separate set of proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG quashed the firstinstance decision to dismiss the proceedings and to transfer the case to ORG and returned the case to ORG . It held , inter alia , that proceedings before ORG could not be started by dismissing and transferring a civil case pending before a civil court .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG asked the applicant to provide further and more specific particulars of claim , namely to justify it and to adduce evidence in support of his claim within DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant amended his claim . He argued that the renaming of the street and the existence of a street bearing the name of Dr. PERSON had violated his right to life , personal freedom and human dignity and had damaged his reputation . He felt ashamed of a municipality which had promoted fascism and had honoured a war criminal . He further stated that he was worried about fundamental human rights and freedoms and democracy in GPE being jeopardised . He added that he identified himself with GPE and he could not be indifferent towards any of its citizens who might become a victim of the consequences of the promotion of fascism .

CARDINAL . On DATE at an oral hearing ORG joined the proceedings concerning the renaming of the street after Dr. PERSON and those seeking the payment of compensation . The applicant further specified his claim . The applicant stated , inter alia , that his aim had been to prevent a repetition of the murder of CARDINAL of people in the future . He claimed that he had been mocked by some of his friends as a result of the public act in issue .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s claim .
CARDINAL . As to the applicant ’s arguments relating to the alleged violation of his personal integrity , ORG held :

“ The fact that a street in the village of PERSON was given the name of Dr. PERSON , which was decided upon by the municipal council and in consequence of which the street exists , can not be considered as an action which is objectively capable of affecting the applicant ’s right to life , his personal freedom , his reputation and dignity . This act ( the decision of the municipal council ) is not aimed , concretely and directly , at the applicant ’s personality or at his personal integrity . The claimant did not prove that the defendant had unlawfully infringed his right to protection of his personality or infringed his personal integrity . The claimant did not prove that , as a consequence of the defendant ’s action , he suffered any damage that should be compensated . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed .
CARDINAL . At a hearing on DATE ORG upheld ORG judgment .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed on points of law . He argued that he had not been allowed to comment on all the evidence and statements led by the defendant and that he had been prevented from presenting his arguments by the trial court .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the appeal on points of law as inadmissible . ORG held that TIME of the hearing before ORG showed that the applicant had been given an opportunity to respond to the defendant ’s arguments . It further held that the only evidence before the court had been a recording of a television programme produced by the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained before ORG under LAW that the relevant part of the resolution of the municipal council , the decisions of ORG and ORG to dismiss the applicant ’s complaints ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , the conduct of ORG and the conduct and decisions of ORG and of ORG had , inter alia , violated his rights under LAW and CARDINAL of the Convention .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the complaint relating to the municipal council ’s resolution and to the conduct of ORG as belated . The complaint relating to the decision of ORG and ORG was rejected because the applicant had failed to complain to higher levels of the prosecution service . The complaint of delays in the proceedings before ORG was rejected as manifestly ill - founded , as at the time of the introduction of the constitutional complaint the proceedings had no longer been pending before ORG . ORG also held that it lacked jurisdiction to deal with the complaint related to the proceedings before ORG , as the proceedings concerning the appeal on points of law were still pending .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again complained to ORG under LAW . He directed his complaint against the relevant part of the municipal council ’s resolution , the conduct of ORG , the conduct and decisions of ORG and of ORG and ORG decision to dismiss the appeal on points of law .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the complaint relating to the municipal council ’s resolution and to the District and the Regional Courts’ conduct and decisions on the grounds that it concerned a matter that was res judicata . ORG further held that ORG decision had been adequately reasoned and had not been arbitrary . The complaint related to ORG decision was therefore dismissed as being manifestly ill - founded .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant complained to ORG for the third time , directing his complaint exclusively against ORG decision .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the complaint as inadmissible on the grounds that the matter was res judicata by force of its earlier decision .

CARDINAL . According to LAW , the ORG shall decide on complaints against final decisions of central and local ORG administrative bodies and municipal bodies which are claimed to have infringed fundamental rights and freedoms , unless the protection of such rights and freedoms falls within the jurisdiction of a different court .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that streets shall be named after objects , natural phenomena , significant events , towns , deceased persons and so forth , having regard to the history of the relevant municipality and its surroundings . The names of living persons , names which are too long , which are identical to the name of another street in the municipality , which offend moral , religious and/or national feelings , which are linguistically incorrect , which are inappropriate with regard to the historical development of the municipality , its wards or its surroundings , are impermissible as street names .

CARDINAL . Subsection CARDINAL of section CARDINAL provides that names of streets shall be decided by a municipal council after consulting with the municipality ’s citizens and after obtaining the opinion of ORG established by ORG .
CARDINAL . The right to the protection of a person ’s dignity , honour , reputation and good name is guaranteed by Articles CARDINAL et seq . of LAW .

CARDINAL . According to LAW , any natural person has the right to the protection of his or her personality , in particular of his or her life and health , civil and human dignity , privacy , name and personal characteristics .

CARDINAL . According to LAW , any natural person has the right to request that an unjustified infringement of his or her personality rights be stopped and the consequences of such infringement eliminated , and to obtain appropriate compensation .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that , in cases where the compensation obtained under LAW is insufficient , in particular because a person ’s dignity and position in society has been considerably diminished , the injured person is entitled to compensation for non - pecuniary damage .
CARDINAL . In accordance with established practice , a claimant has to prove that the alleged infringement was objectively capable of affecting his or her rights under LAW .

CARDINAL . The Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination , established under LAW , adopted an opinion in the case of PERSON v. GPE , ORG . In DATE the NORP petitioner complained before the ORG that the grandstand of an important sporting ground in GPE , GPE , GPE , where the applicant lived , was named the ORG “ ORG .
CARDINAL . The applicant contended that the term “ nigger ” was CARDINAL of the most racially offensive words in the LANGUAGE language .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG held that use and maintenance of the term “ can at the present time be considered offensive and insulting , even if for an extended period it may not have necessarily been so regarded . ”

CARDINAL . ORG stated that ORG “ must be interpreted and applied taking into account the circumstances of contemporary society . In this context , the ORG considers it to be its duty to recall the increased sensitivities in respect of words such as the offending term appertaining DATE . ”
